definitions: strive to gain or win something by defeating or establishing superiority over others
engage in a contest or rivalry to achieve a goal or prize
examples: Athletes compete fiercely for Olympic gold medals
Small businesses compete with larger corporations for market share
The candidates will compete in three televised debates
Several firms competed for the lucrative government contract

definitions: convert source code written in a programming language into machine code that can be executed
collect and combine information or materials from various sources into a single organized document
examples: The software needs several minutes to compile the source code
You must compile the program before running the application
Researchers compiled data from hundreds of scientific studies
She compiled a comprehensive list of local restaurants

definitions: express dissatisfaction or annoyance about something perceived as wrong or unsatisfactory
make a formal accusation or protest to an authority about something
examples: Customers constantly complain about the slow service here
My neighbor complains whenever I play music after nine
She complained to management about workplace harassment issues
Citizens complained to the city council about traffic problems

definitions: add to something in a way that enhances or improves it by providing what is lacking
combine well with something else to form a balanced or attractive whole
examples: This wine perfectly complements the spicy seafood dish
Her technical skills complement his creative design abilities
The curtains complement the wall color beautifully throughout
These accessories complement your outfit without overwhelming it

definitions: finish making or doing something by adding all necessary parts or steps
make something whole or perfect by adding what is missing or needed
examples: Students must complete their assignments before Friday afternoon
The construction crew completed the bridge ahead of schedule
Please complete the form with all required information
This final piece completes our extensive art collection

definitions: make something more difficult or confusing by adding extra elements or problems
introduce factors that make a situation harder to understand or resolve
examples: Don't complicate matters by involving more people unnecessarily
Technical jargon often complicates simple explanations for beginners
Weather conditions complicated the rescue operation significantly yesterday
His arrival complicated an already tense family situation

definitions: express praise or admiration for someone's achievements, appearance, or qualities
convey respect or acknowledgment through positive remarks about someone or something
examples: The chef complimented us on our excellent wine selection
Strangers often compliment her on her beautiful singing voice
He complimented the team's hard work during the meeting
Guests complimented the host on the elegant party decorations

definitions: act in accordance with rules, regulations, or someone's wishes or commands
meet specified standards or conditions set by law or authority
examples: All employees must comply with company safety regulations
The tenant refused to comply with the eviction notice
Manufacturers must comply with strict environmental standards here
The software complies with international data protection laws

definitions: create a piece of music through original writing and arrangement of notes
write something, especially a formal letter or literary work, with careful thought
form or make up the constituent parts of something as a whole
examples: Mozart composed his first symphony at age eight
She composes beautiful melodies for contemporary jazz ensembles
He composed a heartfelt letter to his estranged daughter
The poet composed several sonnets during her Italian vacation
Water molecules compose approximately sixty percent of human bodies
Seven members compose the board of directors

definitions: undergo or cause organic matter to undergo decomposition into nutrient-rich soil
collect and process organic waste materials to create natural fertilizer for gardens
examples: Kitchen scraps compost faster when mixed with dry leaves
These materials will compost naturally over several months
We compost all our vegetable peelings and coffee grounds
The community center composts food waste from local restaurants

definitions: combine two or more elements, substances, or parts to form a whole
increase or enhance something by adding to it progressively over time
make a problem or difficult situation worse by adding complications
examples: Pharmacists compound medications according to specific patient needs
The chemist compounds various elements to create new materials
Interest compounds monthly on this high-yield savings account
Small daily improvements compound into significant long-term results
His lies only compounded the original problem significantly
Poor weather conditions compounded the traffic delays yesterday

definitions: grasp the nature, significance, or meaning of something through mental capacity
include or contain something as a constituent part within a broader scope
examples: Young children cannot comprehend abstract mathematical concepts easily
She struggled to comprehend the complex legal document
This insurance policy comprehends coverage for natural disasters
The survey comprehends all aspects of customer satisfaction

definitions: consist of or be made up of multiple parts or elements as components
form or constitute a whole when multiple parts come together
examples: The committee comprises twelve members from different departments
The exhibition comprises paintings from three private collections
These states comprise the northeastern region of the country
Students and faculty comprise the university's academic community

definitions: settle a dispute by mutual concession where each party gives up some demands
expose something to risk or danger, especially regarding security or integrity
examples: Both parties agreed to compromise on the contract terms
We need to compromise if we want this deal done
Hackers compromised the company's database containing customer information
His reckless behavior compromised the entire mission's success

definitions: calculate or determine a numerical result through mathematical operations or formulas
process information or data using computational methods or computer systems
examples: Engineers compute the stress tolerance of bridge materials
The software computes tax deductions automatically for users
Modern processors compute billions of operations per second
The system computes optimal routes based on traffic data

definitions: deceive someone through fraud or trickery to obtain money or personal gain
study or examine something carefully and thoroughly, especially to memorize
examples: The scammer conned elderly victims out of their savings
Don't let smooth talkers con you into bad investments
Students conned their notes before the important examination
She conned the script until she knew every line

definitions: prevent something from being seen or found by covering or hiding it
keep information, feelings, or intentions secret from others deliberately
examples: The thieves concealed stolen jewelry in hidden wall compartments
Makeup can conceal blemishes and skin imperfections effectively
He concealed his illness from family members for months
The company concealed financial losses from its investors

definitions: admit or acknowledge something is true after first denying or resisting it
surrender or give up a position, right, or possession often under pressure
examples: The defendant finally conceded that he was present there
Critics concede the film has stunning visual effects
The losing candidate conceded defeat after the final count
Management conceded several points during labor negotiations yesterday

definitions: form or devise an idea, plan, or concept in the mind through imagination
become pregnant with a child through biological reproduction
create or design something original through creative thought and planning
examples: Scientists conceived a revolutionary approach to cancer treatment
She couldn't conceive how anyone could be so cruel
The couple tried for years to conceive a child
Many women conceive within six months of trying
Architects conceived an innovative design for the museum
The founder conceived the business during her college years

definitions: direct one's mental effort and attention on a particular object or activity
gather or cause to gather together in one place or area
make a liquid or solution denser by removing water or diluting elements
examples: Students need silence to concentrate on their studies
I can't concentrate with all this noise around me
Troops concentrated near the border before the offensive
Wealth concentrates in major metropolitan areas over time
The factory concentrates orange juice by removing excess water
Boiling concentrates the sauce to intensify its flavor

definitions: form a concept or idea of something in the mind through abstract thinking
create a mental representation or framework to understand complex ideas or systems
examples: Children gradually conceptualize mathematical relationships through hands-on learning
Artists conceptualize their vision before creating the artwork
Engineers conceptualize new designs using computer modeling software
It's difficult to conceptualize infinity or fourth dimensions

definitions: relate to or be about a particular subject, person, or situation
cause anxiety or worry about something that might happen or exist
be important to or affect someone directly in terms of interest or welfare
examples: This report concerns the company's financial performance last quarter
The new regulations concern all small business owners
Parents naturally concern themselves with their children's safety
Environmental issues increasingly concern young voters worldwide
This matter doesn't concern you, so please stay out
The decision concerns everyone in this department equally

definitions: arrange or coordinate actions with others to achieve a common purpose
plan or devise something together through mutual agreement and cooperation
examples: The allies concerted their military strategies before the operation
We must concert our efforts to meet the deadline
The teams concerted a response to the crisis yesterday
Directors concerted plans for the company's international expansion

definitions: bring something to an end or finish it after completing all parts
arrive at a judgment or opinion by reasoning from evidence or premises
make a final decision or judgment about something after consideration
examples: The speaker concluded her presentation with inspiring remarks
The ceremony concluded at midnight with spectacular fireworks
Scientists concluded that climate change caused the phenomenon
The jury concluded he was guilty beyond reasonable doubt
After much deliberation, they concluded to sell the property
Management concluded that restructuring was necessary for survival

definitions: cover or pave a surface with concrete material for construction purposes
make something definite, specific, or real rather than vague or abstract
examples: Workers will concrete the driveway early tomorrow morning
They concreted over the old garden to create parking
We need to concrete our plans before the meeting
The agreement concretes their partnership for five years

definitions: agree with someone or have the same opinion about something
happen at the same time or coincide in occurrence or timing
examples: The board members concur with the CEO's strategic vision
Medical experts concur that exercise improves mental health
Several events concurred to create the perfect storm
His birthday concurs with the national holiday this year

definitions: express complete disapproval of something or someone, typically in public
sentence someone to a particular punishment, especially death, in court
officially declare a building unfit for use or habitation
examples: Human rights groups condemn the government's violent crackdown
Religious leaders condemned the terrorist attacks immediately
The judge condemned the murderer to life imprisonment
The court condemned him to death for his crimes
City inspectors condemned the old factory as structurally unsafe
The health department condemned the restaurant after inspection

definitions: make something denser or more concentrated by removing unnecessary parts or moisture
express written or spoken material in fewer words while retaining meaning
change from gas or vapor into liquid through cooling or pressure
examples: The cook condensed the broth by simmering it slowly
Time constraints forced us to condense the presentation
She condensed the lengthy report into two concise pages
The editor condensed three chapters into one summary
Water vapor condenses on cold window surfaces in winter
Steam condenses into droplets when it hits cold air

definitions: train or influence someone or something to behave in a particular way
make something dependent on particular circumstances or requirements being met
bring something into a desired state of fitness, health, or readiness
examples: Years of advertising conditioned consumers to expect sales
The dog was conditioned to respond to voice commands
The bank conditioned the loan on property appraisal results
They conditioned their support on specific policy changes
Athletes condition their bodies through rigorous daily training
This treatment conditions dry and damaged hair effectively

definitions: accept or allow behavior that is considered morally wrong or offensive
deliberately overlook or forgive an offense without protest or censure
examples: The school cannot condone bullying under any circumstances
We don't condone violence as a solution to problems
Parents who condone underage drinking face legal consequences
The manager seemed to condone his employees' tardiness

definitions: organize and carry out a particular activity, task, or piece of work
behave in a specified way, especially in public or formal situations
transmit heat, electricity, or sound through a material or substance
examples: Scientists conduct experiments to test their hypotheses carefully
The orchestra conductor will conduct Beethoven's Ninth Symphony
Students must conduct themselves appropriately during school assemblies
The diplomat conducted herself with grace under pressure
Copper conducts electricity better than most other metals
Water conducts sound waves faster than air does

definitions: form or shape something into a cone or conical form
mark off an area using traffic cones for safety or direction
examples: The potter coned the clay into a perfect point
Workers coned the metal sheets for the roof structure
Police coned off the accident scene for investigation
Construction crews coned the lane closure on the highway

definitions: grant or bestow a title, degree, benefit, or right upon someone formally
have discussions or exchange views with someone to reach a decision
examples: The university confers degrees upon graduates each spring
The Queen conferred knighthood on the distinguished scientist
Lawyers conferred with their clients before the trial
The committee will confer about the budget proposal tomorrow

definitions: admit or acknowledge that one has committed a crime or done wrong
admit or state that one has done something that one is ashamed of
examples: The suspect confessed to stealing the jewelry yesterday
She confessed her involvement in the conspiracy reluctantly
He finally confessed his true feelings to her
I must confess that I don't understand the problem

definitions: tell someone about a secret or private matter while trusting them
trust someone enough to tell them private or personal information
examples: She confided her deepest fears to her therapist
He rarely confides in anyone about personal matters
I can confide in you because you keep secrets
Teenagers often confide in friends rather than parents

definitions: set up or arrange computer hardware or software for specific operation
arrange or organize the components of something in a particular way
examples: IT staff will configure your new laptop before delivery
Users can configure privacy settings in their account
Engineers configured the machine for maximum efficiency yesterday
You can configure the workspace to suit your needs

definitions: keep or restrict someone or something within certain limits of space
restrict something within certain limits of subject, activity, or area
examples: The prisoners were confined to their cells after sunset
Illness confined her to bed for several weeks
Please confine your remarks to the topic at hand
The study confines itself to urban population data only

definitions: establish the truth, accuracy, or validity of something through evidence
make a provisional arrangement or appointment definite and certain
reinforce or strengthen someone's opinion, belief, or feeling
examples: Blood tests confirmed the doctor's initial diagnosis yesterday
Please confirm your attendance by replying to this email
The hotel confirmed our reservation for next weekend
She called to confirm her appointment with the dentist
Recent events confirm my suspicions about their intentions
The evidence confirms what witnesses told the police

definitions: take or seize someone's property with authority, especially as a penalty
take possession of something by legal right or official authority
examples: Airport security confiscated his pocket knife before boarding
Police confiscated illegal drugs during the raid yesterday
The government confiscated assets obtained through criminal activity
Teachers confiscate phones that disrupt classroom learning

definitions: come into collision or disagreement with opposing forces or ideas
be incompatible or at variance with something else
examples: The protesters conflicted with police during the demonstration
Their interests conflict with our company's long-term goals
The meeting times conflict with my work schedule
These two theories conflict in their basic assumptions

definitions: comply with rules, standards, or laws established by authority or convention
be similar in form or type to something else or match its shape
examples: All products must conform to international safety standards
Students are expected to conform to school dress codes
The design conforms perfectly to the original architectural plans
The software conforms to industry standard protocols exactly

definitions: cause surprise or confusion in someone, especially by acting against expectations
prove a theory, expectation, or prediction wrong through contradictory evidence
examples: The magician's tricks confounded the entire audience completely
His sudden resignation confounded his closest colleagues
The results confounded all our predictions about voter behavior
New discoveries confounded established scientific theories

definitions: face up to and deal with a difficult situation or person directly
challenge someone about something, especially in an aggressive or hostile way
examples: She finally confronted her fears of public speaking
We must confront these problems before they get worse
The journalist confronted the politician about corruption allegations
Neighbors confronted him about his loud music last night

definitions: make someone unable to think clearly or understand something properly
mistake one person or thing for another due to similarity
examples: Complex instructions often confuse first-time users completely
Too much information at once will confuse the students
People frequently confuse me with my twin sister
Don't confuse correlation with causation in your analysis

definitions: perform a Latin American dance with dancers forming a long moving line
move in a line formation while dancing to conga music rhythmically
examples: Wedding guests congaed around the reception hall enthusiastically
The crowd began to conga when the band played
Partygoers congaed through the streets during the carnival
Children love to conga at school celebration parties

definitions: combine several different business companies into one large corporation
gather or form into a mass or group of various elements
examples: Small tech firms conglomerated to compete with industry giants
The company conglomerated several subsidiaries under one brand
Sediments conglomerate at the river delta over centuries
Various interest groups conglomerated to form the coalition

definitions: express pleasure or acknowledgment to someone for an achievement or good fortune
praise someone for their success or good fortune with warm approval
examples: Everyone congratulated the newly married couple at the reception
The manager congratulated her team on exceeding sales targets
I congratulate you on your well-deserved promotion
Friends congratulated him for winning the championship

definitions: gather into a crowd or mass in one place for a purpose
come together in a group or crowd, especially for religious worship
examples: Students congregate in the cafeteria during lunch breaks
Protesters congregated outside the government building peacefully
The faithful congregate at the mosque every Friday
Birds congregate at the lake during migration season

definitions: form an opinion or supposition about something on incomplete information
make a guess about something based on incomplete evidence or information
examples: Scientists conjecture that dark matter comprises most universal mass
Historians can only conjecture about ancient civilization practices
Without more data, we can only conjecture the cause
Experts conjecture the painting dates from the Renaissance

definitions: give the different forms of a verb in grammar according to tense and person
join together, especially in pairs, for a common purpose or function
combine or unite chemically to form a complex compound or molecule
examples: Students must conjugate irregular French verbs for homework
The teacher asked us to conjugate verbs in past tense
The proteins conjugate to form more complex structures
These cells conjugate during the reproduction process
Enzymes conjugate amino acids to create new compounds
The molecules conjugate through chemical bonding processes
